snippet: States not complying with federal requirements for extra safety features in driving licenses gain a two-year extension before residents must use a passport or other government ID to board a flight.
abstract: Department of Homeland Security gives six states and territories until January 2018 to issue drivers licenses with extra safety features per federal requirements; if deadline isn't met, residents of those states will need passport or other official documents to board domestic flights.
lead_paragraph: States not complying with federal requirements for extra safety features in driving licenses gain a two-year extension before residents must use a passport or other government ID to board a flight.

headline.main: U.S. Gives States 2 More Years to Meet Driver’s License Standards
headline.print_headline: Federal Government Gives States 2 Additional Years to Meet Driver’s License Standards
